conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks light from the light source.
The shape and size of the shadow depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface where the shadow is cast.
When the light source is closer to the object, the shadow is larger and more distorted.
As the light source moves farther away, the shadow becomes smaller and more similar in shape to the object.
Moving the light source backward increases the distance between the light source and the objects.
Increased distance causes shadows to become smaller because light rays will be more parallel, resulting in less distortion.
As the light source moves backward, the direction of the light rays changes slightly, causing shadows to shift slightly in position.
Shadows will move closer to the objects because the angle of the light rays will be less steep.
Shadows will become smaller as the light source moves backward due to more parallel light rays.
Final answer: Shadows A, B, C, and D will shrink in size and move closer to their respective objects.
